note.p: Cartouche (MS III)—On the title page, Ruskin encases the first line of the title in a rectangle, which includes scrolls or leaf ornaments, as if imitating a cartouche in a printed book. He also places the numeral 2 on opposite ends of the rectangle, both as ornamentation and declaration of his second volume.
"going" (MS III)—In light pencil below the caption, Ruskin practiced writing the word going.
Justification mark (MS III)—See Editorial and Encoding Rationale and Methodology: Element, Attribute, and Value Usage—Justification, Runover, and Word Division.

Unidentified superscript mark (MS III)—The meaning of the superscript character between the l and the s is obscure. Perhaps Ruskin started to form an apostrophe but stopped as he realized his error in making a plural into a possessive.

Double period followed by a single quotation mark (MS III)—Ruskin uses this baffling punctuation twice in this second volume of "Harry and Lucy", consisting of two punctuation marks that in themselves are usages apparently of his own invention and obscure in their purpose--one, the double period; and the other, a closing quotation mark unaccompanied by an opening quotation mark, which here happens to be a single quotation mark (see Editorial and Encoding Rationale and Methodology: Element, Attribute, and Value Usage—Commas, Periods, Quotation Marks, and Other Punctuation). It is unclear whether Ruskin brought these two marks together to form a distinct, single punctuation mark--in the second instance, combined even with a third, a vertical squiggly line--or whether in his mind the marks retained their separate functions. Whatever his intention or the origin of the invention, the two instances in "Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2" appear to signify a break in the narrative, a shift from one episode to another.

Double period (MS III)—For Ruskin's invention, the double period, see Editorial and Encoding Rationale and Methodology: Element, Attribute, and Value Usage—Commas, Periods, Quotation Marks, and Other Punctuation.
